references: Finally, we analyze the time complexity of the proposed method, as well as several existing competitors including LightGCN [5], SGL-ED  [5], SGL-ED [8], SimGCL  [8], SimGCL [11], and XSimGCL  [11], and XSimGCL [12]. The analysis is based on a single batch, and the results are shown in Table  [12]. The analysis is based on a single batch, and the results are shown in Table 1, where we intentionally keep the ordinal numbers for better clarity. references: Next, we compare the performance of various embedding perturbation methods with XSimGCL [12] as the backbone network, and the results are shown in Table  [12] as the backbone network, and the results are shown in Table 4. XSimGCL uses random uniform perturbation noise with sign constraints, ‘Gaussian’ represents Gaussian noise, and ‘EP’ represents the noise generated by AvoGCL. S4.T5.caption: Table 5: Relation between graph redundancy and model performance. Lower redundancy leads to better performance.
S4.T5.table:
Method Yelp Gowalla Amazon
R@20 N@20 Sim R@20 N@20 Sim R@20 N@20 Sim
SGL 0.1279 0.0822 99.77% 0.1928 0.1240 99.68% 0.1316 0.0834 99.76%
SGL_pos 0.1308 0.0841 99.21% 0.1968 0.1272 99.49% 0.1347 0.0856 99.38%
SGL_both 0.1315 0.0849 98.37% 0.1979 0.1278 98.92% 0.1352 0.0863 99.03%
references:
The experimental results are shown in Table 5.
We can observer that, as the graph redundancy decreases, the performance increases. This result also confirms that the proposed structure perturbator can successfully lower the graph redundancy and thus improve the performance.
Also, we find that allowing the model to add edges as well as delete edges results in better performance.

references: In order to evaluate the impact of noisy interactions on model performance, we randomly injected 20% edges to the training set and retrain the model. We compare AvoGCL with other methods, and the results are shown in Table 6. We observe that AvoGCL still achieves the best results in all cases compared to the baselines. For example, on the Yelp dataset, AvoGCL increases the NDCG@10 metric of the best competitor by 7.2%.
